task.title: Adding elements to the DITA map
task.shortdesc: After you create a DITA map, you can use to add <topicref> elements to the map, define @navtitle and @collection-type attributes, and more.

context.p: This procedure is designed to help you become familiar with using to add <topicref> elements to a DITA map.
When you have completed this exercise, you will be able to complete the following tasks:

ul.li:
Add <topicref> elements using any of the following methods:
Menu
Keyboard
Right-click menu
Change the node type, both before and after you have created nodes in the model
Move a node by dragging and dropping
Save a DITA map that you have modified

context.p: You also will understand some of the terminology used by and how it maps to DITA terminology.

step.cmd: To specify that the DITA map is displayed as a hierarchical diagram, click View View As Hierarchical Diagram .
To turn off the relationship visualization, click View Hide All Visualization .
Add a top-level <topicref> element. In the terminology used by , this is a disconnected node.

substep.cmd: To select a <topicref> element with the type of task, press Ctrl+T, click Task, and then click OK.
To add the <topicref> element, click Node Add disconnected node .
Type Dental hygiene, and press Enter.
substep.info: The text that you typed is the @navtitle attribute of the <topicref> element.

step.stepresult: A node appears in the Map Editor view. Dental hygiene node

step.cmd: Add a child <topicref> element by using the keyboard. In the terminology used by , this is a child node.

substep.cmd: Press Alt+Down arrow.
Type Brushing your teeth, and press Enter.
substep.info: Since you previously had selected the type of task, a task <topicref> element is added to the DITA map.

step.cmd: Add a sibling <topicref> element by using the right-click context menu. In the terminology used by , this is a sibling node.

substep.cmd: Select the "Brushing your teeth" node, right-click and click Add Next Sibling.
Type Flossing your teeth, and press Enter.

image.alt: Dental hygiene node with two child nodes

substep.cmd: On the menu bar, click the Choose Node Type icon.
In the Choose Node Type window, click Concept, and then click OK.

step.cmd: Add a sibling <topicref> element by using the keyboard:

substep.cmd: Select the "Flossing your teeth" node, and press Ctrl+Right arrow.
Type Dental products, and then press Enter.

step.cmd: Add three children of the "Dental products" <topicref> element:

substep.cmd: Select the "Dental products" node, and click Node Add Child ..
Press Ctrl+Right arrow
Right-click, and then click Add Next Sibling.
Press Enter.

step.stepresult: Mode cluster that contains topic references without names Three <topicref> elements have been added to the DITA map, but none of them have navtitle atttributes. In terminology, navtitle attributes are the names of the nodes.

substep.cmd: Click the 3.1 node, type Toothbrush, and press Enter.
Click the 3.2 node, type Toothpaste, and press Enter.
Click the 3.3 node, type Dental floss, and press Enter.

step.cmd: Add a <topicref> element after the "Dental products" topic:

substep.cmd: Click the "Dental products" topic to select it.
substep.stepresult: The node turns yellow and has a black border around it.

substep.cmd: To add a child topic, press Ctrl+Down arrow.
Type Tooth and gum disease, and press Enter.

step.cmd: Add three children of the "Tooth and gum disease" <topicref> element. Use whatever method – menu, keyboard, and right-click context menu – that you prefer.

substep.cmd: Add a node with the name "Cavities.
Add a node with the name "Periodontal disease."
Add a node with the name "Stages of tooth decay."

step.stepresult: Since the node type was set to Concept, you added three <topicref type="concept> elements. However, you really wanted the "Stages of tooth decay" topic to be a reference topic.

step.cmd: Change the type of node 4 ("Stages of tooth decay") to reference:

substep.cmd: Select the node that you want to modify.
If it is not open, open the Properties view by clicking Window Show View Properties .
In the Properties window, scroll upwards and locate the Node type property.
Click in the Value field, and select Reference.

image.alt: Screen capture showing process of changing a node type

substep.cmd: Click in the Map Editor view.
substep.stepresult: The node type is changed to Reference. Updated node cluster

step.cmd: Set a collection-type attribute for the "Dental products" <topicref> element:

substep.cmd: Click Unspecified.
substep.info: This label is located to the left of the "Dental products" node.
substep.stepresult: The Edit Collection type window opens.

substep.cmd: Select Family, and click OK.

step.stepresult:
A label for the collection-type attribute is displayed in the Map Editor view.
Next, you decide that you want to add a container topic that will hold the toothbrushing and flossing tasks, and that you will set a collection-type attribute of sequence on the container topic. (This will help readers understand that toothbrushing and flossing are tasks that should be performed in a certain order.

step.cmd: Add a <topicref> element as a parent of the "Brushing your teeth" topic:

substep.cmd: Select the type as Task.
Select the "Brushing your teeth" topic, and press Ctrl+Up arrow.
Type Caring for your teeth.
Select the topic and drag it down until it touches the right side of the "Brushing your teeth" node.
When a Move task 2 as next sibling of 1.1 label is displayed, release the node.

step.stepresult: The topic is displayed in a different place in model, and has reassigned the node IDs.

step.cmd: Set the collection-type attribute to Sequence.
step.stepresult: The model now looks like this: The completed dental hygience cluster
